title-group.article-title: French Intellectuals and the Palestine Question

bio.p: Farouk Mardam-Bey is the author of numerous books and essays on cultural history, politics, Arabic poetry, and food. Mardam-Bey was the editor ofJPS's French-language sister publication,Revue des Études Palestiniennes, for 27 years and is currently the head of Sindbad, an imprint of the prestigious French publisher, Actes-Sud. This article was originally published in French in Confluences Méditerranée (No. 72, 2010).

abstract.p: This article focuses on intellectuals—writers, philosophers, academics, scientists, and artists—who, by virtue of their accomplishments and talents, or simply because of their renown, wielded such moral authority that they became at times veritable “leaders of conscience,” influencing public opinion and, indeed, government policy in France. Responding to major events, whether colonial wars, international crises, or significant domestic political battles, French intellectuals weighed in time and again, from the Dreyfus affair to the bogus Sarkozy debate on “national identity.” 1 This article reviews the stance of French intellectuals on the question of Palestine and the wider Arab-Israeli conflict, and examines how the ideological and political assumptions underlying their positions were not always amenable to rational explanation or easily ascribed to traditional attitudes of the Left and Right.

It should be made clear here that, since the 1950s, the extreme Right in France has in its great majority been and continues to be pro-Israeli, its Arabophobia and Islamophobia being far greater than its anti-Semitism.

Thanks to the support of the Socialist Party and the Paris media world, SOS Racisme (founded in 1984) was able to rapidly marginalize the young people of North African immigrant origin who, on 15 October 1983, had launched the “March for Equality and against Racism” from Marseille to Paris.

It is remarkable that the Front National (FN) has avoided taking a stand on the Palestinian question, although Marine Le Pen is trying to draw closer to Israel in order to circumvent the hostility of French Jews toward her party. The interventions of the FN concerning Near Eastern affairs are rare, but they are significant: for example, support for Saddam Hussein in the past and for Bashar al-Assad at present.
